snippet: Facing a sluggish economy and increasing competition, Japan’s prime minister and major companies want to reduce longstanding restrictions on dismissing full-time workers.
abstract: Japanese Prime Min Shinzo Abe and major Japanese companies hope to reduce longstanding restrictions on dismissing full-time workers as way to jump start the economy and increase competition; fewer restrictions on layoffs could make it easier for companies like Sony to leave loss-ridden traditional businesses and concentrate resources on more innovative, promising ones.

byline.contributor: Joshua Hunt contributed research from Tokyo.

lead_paragraph: Facing a sluggish economy and increasing competition, Japan’s prime minister and major companies want to reduce longstanding restrictions on dismissing full-time workers.

headline.main: Layoffs Taboo, Japan Workers Are Sent to the Boredom Room
